title: Glaisher's theorem
summary: In number theory, Glaisher's theorem is an identity useful to the study of integer partitions.  Proved in 1883[1] by James Whitbread Lee Glaisher, it states that the number of partitions of an integer n {\displaystyle n} into parts not divisible by d {\displaystyle d} is equal to the number of partitions in which no part is repeated d {\displaystyle d} or more times. This generalizes a result established in 1748 by Leonhard Euler for the case d = 2 {\displaystyle d=2} .
